children.name: Editor

comment.text:
```ts
import f from './Provider'

```

comment.shortText: If set, `this.context` will be set at runtime to the current value of the given Context.

Called immediately before mounting occurs, and before `Component#render`.
Avoid introducing any side-effects or subscriptions in this method.
comment.text:
This method will not stop working in React 17.

Note: the presence of getSnapshotBeforeUpdate or getDerivedStateFromProps
prevents this from being invoked.

tags.text: 16.3, use componentDidMount or the constructor instead

comment.shortText:
Called when the component may be receiving new props.
React may call this even if props have not changed, so be sure to compare new and existing
props if you only want to handle changes.
comment.text:
Calling `Component#setState` generally does not trigger this method.

This method will not stop working in React 17.

Note: the presence of getSnapshotBeforeUpdate or getDerivedStateFromProps
prevents this from being invoked.

comment.shortText: Called immediately before rendering when new props or state is received. Not called for the initial render.
comment.text:
Note: You cannot call `Component#setState` here.

This method will not stop working in React 17.

Note: the presence of getSnapshotBeforeUpdate or getDerivedStateFromProps
prevents this from being invoked.

comment.shortText: Called immediately after a component is mounted. Setting state here will trigger re-rendering.
Called immediately after updating occurs. Not called for the initial render.
comment.text: The snapshot is only present if getSnapshotBeforeUpdate is present and returns non-null.

comment.shortText:
Called immediately before mounting occurs, and before `Component#render`.
Avoid introducing any side-effects or subscriptions in this method.
comment.text:
Note: the presence of getSnapshotBeforeUpdate or getDerivedStateFromProps
prevents this from being invoked.

tags.text: 16.3, use componentDidMount or the constructor instead; will stop working in React 17

comment.shortText:
Called when the component may be receiving new props.
React may call this even if props have not changed, so be sure to compare new and existing
props if you only want to handle changes.
comment.text:
Calling `Component#setState` generally does not trigger this method.

Note: the presence of getSnapshotBeforeUpdate or getDerivedStateFromProps
prevents this from being invoked.

tags.text: 16.3, use static getDerivedStateFromProps instead; will stop working in React 17

comment.shortText:
Called immediately before a component is destroyed. Perform any necessary cleanup in this method, such as
cancelled network requests, or cleaning up any DOM elements created in `componentDidMount`.
Called immediately before rendering when new props or state is received. Not called for the initial render.
comment.text:
Note: You cannot call `Component#setState` here.

Note: the presence of getSnapshotBeforeUpdate or getDerivedStateFromProps
prevents this from being invoked.

tags.text: 16.3, use getSnapshotBeforeUpdate instead; will stop working in React 17

comment.shortText:
Runs before React applies the result of `render` to the document, and
returns an object to be given to componentDidUpdate. Useful for saving
things such as scroll position before `render` causes changes to it.
comment.text:
Note: the presence of getSnapshotBeforeUpdate prevents any of the deprecated
lifecycle events from running.

comment.shortText: Called to determine whether the change in props and state should trigger a re-render.
comment.text:
`Component` always returns true.
`PureComponent` implements a shallow comparison on props and state and returns true if any
props or states have changed.

If false is returned, `Component#render`, `componentWillUpdate`
and `componentDidUpdate` will not be called.

comment.shortText:
Creates a react component using the code text as it's body. This allows
using top level hooks in your example without having to create and return your
own component. Cannot be used with `render()` in the example.
comment.text:
```jsx
import Button from './Button'

const [active, setActive] = useState()

<Button active={active} onClick={() => setActive(true)}/>
```

comment.shortText: A function that resolves to a hash of import requests to the result

comment.shortText: Creates a pausable `setInterval` that is properly cleaned up when a component unmounted

The milliseconds duration of the interval

rather than waiting for the first interval to elapse
